titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the Helen Moore Barthelme Papers 1949/2002

did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: This collection contains photographs, correspondence, newspaper clippings, short stories, and articles related to or written by Donald Barthelme and his brothers, Rick, Steve, and Peter Barthelme, as well as notes by Helen Barthelme.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information:
bioghist.p: Helen Barthelme was born December 18, 1927. She graduated as an honors student from Corpus Christi High School at the age of 15. After her parents separated, she moved to Houston with her mother and two sisters. About a year later, around the age of 17, she enrolled at the University of Houston, where she would later meet Donald Barthelme Jr., who would later become a famous author. She became editor of the school newspaper 'The Cougar.' After graduating with her bachelor's degree, she continued to work in the university's public relations department. She briefly left the university to start a corporate career, but returned as director of the Information Office in 1951.

In 1951, she married her first husband Pete Gilpin. The marriage dissolved in 1956, and she married Donald Barthelme shortly thereafter. She left her professional endeavors for a short time in order to become a housewife, but she disliked the role. She soon re-enrolled in philosophy and art classes at the University of Houston. In 1957, she became an account executive for an ad agency, and was invited to teach classes in journalism and literature at a four-year woman's university in Houston called Dominican College.

In 1959, Helen Barthelme started her own ad agency, and continued to teach at Dominican College. She and Donald Barthelme were divorced in 1965. She continued her education, getting her doctorate from the University of Texas at Austin. In 1972, she accepted an appointment with the Department of English at the University of Houston. She went on to become a professor of English at Texas A&M university in College Station. Helen Barthelme had a long and distinguished career as an ad executive and professor. She died of cancer on Jun 28, 2002.

Barthelme, H. M. (2001). Donald Barthelme: The Genesis of a Cool Sound (Tarleton State University Southwestern Studies in the Humanities, 13) (1st ed ed.). College Station: Texas A&M University Press.
Contemporary Authors Online, Gale, 2010. Reproduced in Biography Resource Center. Farmington Hills, Mich.: Gale, 2010. http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/BioRC

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.
Photocopy decisions will be made by Special Collections staff on a case-by-case basis. Patrons are responsible for obtaining permission to publish from copyright holders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographs, correspondence, newspaper clippings, short stories, and articles related to or written by Donald Barthelme and his brothers, Rick, Steve, and Peter Barthelme, as well as notes by Helen Barthelme. This collection contains research that Helen Barthelme gathered in order to write a biography on Donald Barthelme Jr., Donald Barthelme: The Genesis of a Cool Sound. This collection encompasses his early life and career both as a writer and as director of the Contemporary Arts Association, up until his death in 1989.

did.unittitle: Miscelleneous architectural speech, Rice University lectures, etc. (Donald Barthelme Sr.)

scopecontent.p: This series includes copies of typescript program proposals for the Contemporary Arts Association (CAA) and the Contemporary Arts Museum, CAA publications, copies of newspaper articles about CAA, and other miscellaneous materials.
Contains microfiche copies of newspaper articles about CAA during Donald Barthelme's tenureas member of the board and director.

This series includes original, and copies of typescript letters written by Donald Barthelme to his family during his army service in Korea, to Helen Barthelme during and after their marriage, and to friends and family. The series also includes letters to Donald Barthelme from friends, postcards, telegrams, and other miscellaneous items. Some letters included are outside the chronological scope of the early years of Donald Barthelme's life.

This series contains photographs from Donald Barthelme's time in Korea, his selective service cards and honorable discharge certificate from the US Army, and family photographs, slides, negatives, and proofs.

did.unittitle: Beach photos with Jack and Ann Boynton

scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence between Donald Barthelme and contributors to the Forum during 1956-1960, arranged alphabetically by contributor name. Included are letters from such noted contributors as Robert Bly, Irving Howe, Alfred Kazin, Norman Mailer, and Harold Rosenberg. Some folders also include additional materials related to Forum contributors such as reprints of articles, photocopied bibliographies of works, photocopies of obituaries, and annotated lists of correspondence. Also included is correspondence related to a propsed meeting of editors of similar journals and miscellaneous administrative materials.

did.unittitle: Annotated list of letters to Donald Barthelme

Forum Magazine and Miscellaneous Manuscript Materials

scopecontent.p: This series includes original and copies of Forum magazines and other miscellaneous materials.

did.unittitle: University of Houston Forum miscelleneous manuscript materials

scopecontent.p: This series contains several photocopies and originals of the published versions of early short stories by Donald Barthelme, an original typescript of his essay "Not-Knowing," and miscellaneous materials related to Barthelme's writing work. It also includes a listing of the published versions of short stories, which were cataloged and removed from the collection.

did.unittitle: "The Darling Duckling at School," Contact, photocopy
"Not Knowing," typescript and copy, Georgia Review original lecture article.
"The King", uncorrected proof title page, photocopy, description

scopecontent.p: This series contains copies of newspaper and magazine articles about Barthelme and his work, interviews, reviews of works, and miscellaneous critical materials. Also included are programs for book readings of Barthelme's works and receptions honoring Barthelme, as well as the announcement of the Barthelme Memorial Fellowship award.

scopecontent.p: This series includes copies of newspaper articles on the Barthelme brothers, reviews of their works, and essays published by Steven Barthelme. The series also contains copies of 'The Texas Observer' during Steven Barthelme's tenure as review editor and contributor.

scopecontent.p: This series includes notes for Helen Barthelme's book, analysis of Donald Barthelme's works, interviews with friends of Donald Barthelme, biographies and bibliographies of contributors to Forum, newspaper and magazine articles about Donald Barthelme, and other miscellaneous materials.

scopecontent.p: This series includes manuscripts, notes, and diaries by Helen Barthelme, drafts of fictional works, poems, and essays, including Dr. Barthelme's classwork.
